Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The conflicting effects of gene flow in a geographic mosaic of predator-prey coevolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will test the conflicting effects of gene flow in the co-evolutionary arms race between common garter snakes and their toxic prey, Pacific newts. The structure and complexity of ecological communities is shaped by the joint evolution of interacting species. Negative interactions, like predator-prey relationships, are often characterized by sustained and rapid adaptation; each species must constantly adapt and counter-adapt to the co-evolving defenses of its natural enemy. Theory predicts that migration and the exchange of genetic material among populations (a process called gene flow) will have two important, yet conflicting, effects on local adaptation to antagonistic interactions. Gene flow is generally thought to homogenize genetic variation among populations and hinder local adaptation. Conversely, gene flow and migration may play a critical role to spread beneficial mutations to new populations and promote rapid adaptive change. This research will form a foundation for understanding the genetic impetus behind sustained, and often rapid, evolutionary changes that are responsible for the tremendous diversity of complex traits that span predator-prey, host-parasite, and plant-animal systems. In addition, this study will contribute to the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

In western North America, garter snakes (Thamnophis sirtalis) have evolved resistance to tetrodotoxin (TTX), an otherwise lethal neurotoxin found in the newts. Highly resistant snake populations tend to co-occur with highly toxic newts (Taricha species), as coevolution has apparently driven the escalation of armaments in both predator and prey. Toxin resistance in the garter snake is largely due to key amino acid replacements in the NaV1.4 sodium channel protein. This project will use next-generation DNA sequencing to test whether snake gene flow promotes adaptation to toxic newts through the spread of TTX-resistance mutations in the NaV1.4 sodium channel. The researchers will generate two separate genetic datasets from garter snake populations across western North America: (1) genetic variation at the NaV1.4 locus, and (2) background genetic variation, unlinked to NaV1.4, in neutral Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) from double digest Restriction Associated DNA sequencing (ddRADseq). Population structure and gene flow will then be estimated separately for each dataset. Discordant patterns of gene flow between the two datasets will indicate where selection has altered the spread of NaV1.4 haplotypes in relation to neutral expectations of the SNPs. For example, in populations where gene flow and selection favor the spread of TTX-resistance mutations, gene flow at the NaV1.4 locus should exceed that of background variation in the neutral SNPs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interactions between species represent a major driver of biodiversity on Earth. When a pair of interacting species coevolve together through reciprocal changes, the process can result in mutually beneficial relationships (like plants and their pollinators) or antagonistic relationships (like predator and prey). These associations ultimately arise due to evolutionary changes at the molecular interface of the interactions between organisms. Our research found that a small number of mutations at the molecular interface of toxin-binding shape broader patterns of coevolution in the arms race between common garter snakes (Thamnophis sirtalis) and their toxic prey, Pacific newts (Taricha species). 

Garter snakes evolved resistance to tetrodotoxin (TTX), a deadly neurotoxin found in their newt prey. TTX works by binding into voltage-gated sodium channels (NaV) in nerves and muscles, blocking the transmission of electrical signals. We found that two separate geographic lineages of garter snakes independently evolved resistance to toxic newts through the same mutations to the NaV1.4 skeletal muscle sodium channel. This novel pattern suggests evolution is more predictable than previously thought, and convergent traits like TTX resistance can evolve repeatedly through similar sets of mutations. The two lineages of snakes probably share biases in the evolutionary process, whereby only a limited set of mutations can confer toxin resistance to NaV1.4 without disrupting the protein’s function as a voltage-gated sodium channel. The channels otherwise have an evolutionarily conserved structure across all of vertebrates, including humans, because their function in the nervous systemis so important.

We also directly tested whether mutations to the sodium channel generate costs in TTX-resistant garter snakes.Such evolutionary trade-offs are commonly expected to arise during the process of adaptation. We found that snakes with an extremely resistant set of mutations had significantly reduced crawl speed, a whole-animal measure of muscle performance. This same set of mutations also reduces the overall excitability of voltage-gated sodium channels. These results indicate that trade-offs arise as levels of resistance escalate in the arms race with toxic newts. Mutations that beneficially confer toxin resistance can ultimately disrupt sodium channel function in muscle tissue and reduce crawl speed of the snake. This study is one of the first to link a few individual mutations in a conserved protein (NaV1.4) to broad trade-offs in performance at the level of the organism. This evolutionary trade-off likely shapes geographic patterns of adaptation to toxic newts in the arms race.

We continue to analyze the data from this research to test how demography and migration mediate patterns of coevolution. Theory predicts that migration and the exchange of genetic material among populations (a process called gene flow) will have two important, yet conflicting, effects on local adaptation during coevolution. Gene flow is generally thought to homogenize genetic variation among populations and hinder local adaptation. Conversely, gene flow and migration may play a critical role to spread beneficial mutations (e.g., in NaV1.4) to new populations and promote rapid adaptive change. We are currently using next-generation DNA sequencing data to test how patterns of gene flow mediate geographic patterns of newt TTX and snake resistance in the NaV1.4 channel.
